<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 378, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 168, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 259]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 299, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[777, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 213, 618]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 730, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 908, 89]]<|/det|>
A car travels at a speed of \(20 \text{m/s}\). The driver applies the brakes when he sees a red traffic light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 520, 121]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the speed–time graph for the car.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 128, 801, 344]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 358, 532, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 146, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 390, 539, 408]]<|/det|>
Determine the speed of the car at time \(= 2.0 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 435, 920, 455]]<|/det|>
<form>speed of the car = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 469, 148, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 791, 486]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance travelled by the car between time \(= 0\) and time \(= 4.0 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 617, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
<form>distance travelled = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 648, 146, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 648, 769, 667]]<|/det|>
Calculate the deceleration of the car between time \(= 0.5 \text{s}\) and time \(= 4.0 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 800, 920, 819]]<|/det|>
<form>deceleration = ........................................................ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 831, 920, 850]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 751, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows a space vehicle which consists of a capsule and a nose cone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 902, 122]]<|/det|>
The space vehicle is moving at a velocity of \(7800 \text{m/s}\). The mass of the space vehicle is \(840 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 128, 655, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 298, 534, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 146, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 330, 833, 349]]<|/det|>
Show that the momentum of the space vehicle is approximately \(6.55 \times 10^{6} \text{kg} / \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 481, 920, 498]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 510, 146, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 616, 530]]<|/det|>
The capsule ejects the nose cone, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 536, 630, 680]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 699, 591, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 728, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
Determine the velocity \(\nu\) of the capsule after the nose cone is ejected. Give your answer to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 928, 920, 946]]<|/det|>
velocity \(\nu\) of the capsule = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 504, 88]]<|/det|>
A different space capsule returns to Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 85, 628, 103]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.3 shows this capsule just before it lands in the sea.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 485, 120]]<|/det|>
The capsule travels at terminal velocity.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 128, 700, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 388, 534, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 419, 631, 437]]<|/det|>
The upward vertical force acting on the capsule is \(120 \text{kN}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 443, 467]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 635, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
<form>mass of the capsule = ....................................................... [2]

<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 69, 556, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows an archer aiming an arrow at a target.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 98, 855, 299]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 316, 533, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 346, 146, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 346, 920, 381]]<|/det|>
The archer pulls back on the bow string, doing a total of 110J of work. Her hand moves a distance of \(0.45\mathrm{m}\). The bow is bent and stores energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 392, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
Show that the average force applied by the archer in pulling the string back is approximately \(240\mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 559, 920, 578]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 590, 148, 608]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 590, 836, 609]]<|/det|>
The archer releases the bow string. All the energy in **(a)** is transferred to the arrow.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 784, 640]]<|/det|>
The arrow moves off at an initial speed \(v\). The mass of the arrow is \(0.030\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 653, 183, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 653, 530, 670]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 803, 920, 822]]<|/det|>
<form>initial speed \(v =\) .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 834, 180, 853]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 833, 893, 853]]<|/det|>
Explain why the speed of the arrow as it hits the target is less than the value in **(b)**(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 922, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 917, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows a pan with a copper base on a hotplate. The hotplate heats the pan and the water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[298, 97, 700, 203]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 217, 532, 235]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 247, 146, 266]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 247, 707, 266]]<|/det|>
Explain how thermal energy is conducted through the copper base.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 371, 920, 390]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 402, 146, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 402, 180, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 402, 522, 421]]<|/det|>
Define, in words, specific heat capacity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 524, 181, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 524, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
A student heats a metal object to \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The student places the metal object in an insulated cup containing water at \(22^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The final temperature of the water and the metal object is \(31^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 588, 603, 606]]<|/det|>
The specific heat capacity of water is \(4.2 \text{J} / (\text{g} \circ \text{C})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 603, 608, 621]]<|/det|>
The mass of the water in the insulated cup is \(50 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 618, 500, 636]]<|/det|>
The mass of the metal object is \(54 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 650, 593, 668]]<|/det|>
Calculate the specific heat capacity of the metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 867, 920, 885]]<|/det|>
<form>specific heat capacity = .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 899, 920, 917]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 69, 398, 87]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 702, 920, 723]]<|/det|>

The power lost in a cable is \(1.25 \times 10^{-3} \text{W}\). The resistance of the cable is \(0.050 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 765, 435, 784]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 914, 920, 933]]<|/det|>
